articles.headline: A Setback Then a Reprieve for Vonage in Courts
articles.snippet: A federal court gave Vonage a reprieve shortly after a lower court barred it from enrolling new subscribers.
articles.abstract: A federal court gave Vonage a reprieve shortly after a lower court barred it from enrolling new subscribers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vonage Holdings, the Internet phone company, had a wild ride in the courtroom yesterday.

articles.headline: Even as Africa Hungers, Policy Slows Delivery of U.S. Food Aid
articles.snippet: Groups with deep stakes in the current system oppose a proposal that could deliver food aid faster in countries like Zambia, where rations are at risk of running out.
articles.abstract: Groups with deep stakes in the current system oppose a proposal that could deliver food aid faster in countries like Zambia, where rations are at risk of running out.
articles.lead_paragraph: MULONDO, Zambia — Traveling to school in wobbly dugout canoes, Munalula Muhau and her three cousins, 7- and 8-year-olds whose parents had died from AIDS, held onto just one possession: battered tin bowls to receive their daily ration of gruel.

articles.headline: Britons Say They Feared for Lives in Iran Captivity
articles.snippet: Freed sailors and marines said they were subjected to a determined campaign of psychological intimidation.
articles.abstract: Freed sailors and marines said they were subjected to a determined campaign of psychological intimidation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 6 — Their greatest scare, they recalled, came on the second day, when they were flown to Tehran, blindfolded and backed up against a prison wall while their Iranian captors fiddled with weapons, cocking rifles and making them fear for their lives.

articles.headline: Detroit Decides to Help Shape, Not Resist, Regulation of Emissions
articles.snippet: Automakers and their Washington trade group say they want an active role in the movement to reduce the damage vehicles do to the environment.
articles.abstract: Automakers and their Washington trade group say they want an active role in the movement to reduce the damage vehicles do to the environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: The New York International Auto Show, which opened to the public yesterday, is a picture of an industry with a cloud over its head.
articles.byline: By Micheline Maynard and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Sifting Data to Uncover Travel Deals
articles.snippet: A number of Web sites have recently been created that specialize in spotting true airfare bargains.
articles.abstract: A number of Web sites have recently been created that specialize in spotting true airfare bargains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Say you are looking for a deal on an airline flight. The Internet abounds with offers for low fares. You can find them on the major Internet travel agent sites like Orbitz, Travelocity or on more specialized sites like Cheaptickets.com or Sidestep.com.

articles.headline: Piracy Move on China Seen as Near
articles.snippet: The Bush administration appears close to filing a formal trade complaint against China over pirated copies of films, music and software.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration appears close to filing a formal trade complaint against China over pirated copies of films, music and software.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 6 — After months of prodding China to crack down on pirated copies of American movies, music and software, the Bush administration appears ready to escalate the dispute into a legal confrontation.

articles.headline: Well-Meaning but Misguided Stock Screens
articles.snippet: Socially responsible investing oversimplifies the world, creating the illusion that the world is black and white, when its real color is gray.
articles.abstract: Socially responsible investing oversimplifies the world, creating the illusion that the world is black and white, when its real color is gray.

articles.headline: 2 Years After Big Speech, a Lower Key for Obama
articles.snippet: The senator is not presenting himself, stylistically at least, the way he did when he gripped Democrats in 2004.
articles.abstract: The senator is not presenting himself, stylistically at least, the way he did when he gripped Democrats in 2004.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLO, Iowa, April 6 — Senator Barack Obama is not big on what he calls red-meat applause lines when he campaigns in small communities like this one, 45 miles northeast of Des Moines. He does not tell many jokes. He talks in even, measured tones, and at times is so low-key that he lulls his audiences into long, if respectful, silences.

articles.headline: Housing Slump Pinches States in Pocketbook
articles.snippet: State tax revenues are growing more slowly this year and in some cases falling below projections.
articles.abstract: State tax revenues are growing more slowly this year and in some cases falling below projections.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, April 7 — State tax revenues around the country are growing far more slowly this year and in some cases falling below projections, a result of the housing market slowdown that has curbed voracious spending on real estate, building materials, furniture and other items.

articles.headline: Home Loans: A Nightmare Grows Darker
articles.snippet: The original promise of subprime mortgages dissipates.
articles.abstract: The original promise of subprime mortgages dissipates.
articles.lead_paragraph: SNAZZY and newfangled mortgage loans, like those with low initial rates of interest or extended terms of 40 or 50 years, helped to drive homeownership rates in the United States from around 64 percent two decades ago to a peak of almost 70 percent in recent years. Called “affordability loans,” these new kinds of mortgages have gone mostly to first-time home buyers and borrowers with tarnished credit or spotty employment histories.

articles.headline: More Pieces. Still a Puzzle.
articles.snippet: While new disclosure rules have resulted in far more information, analysts say they still do not necessarily offer greater insight into executive compensation.
articles.abstract: While new disclosure rules have resulted in far more information, analysts say they still do not necessarily offer greater insight into executive compensation.
articles.lead_paragraph: “SUNLIGHT,” remarked the Supreme Court justice Louis D. Brandeis, “is said to be the best of disinfectants.” One problem with too much sunlight, however, can be the blinding glare.

articles.headline: North Koreans Arm Ethiopians as U.S. Assents
articles.snippet: The Bush administration allowed the purchase despite U.N. sanctions, according to U.S. officials.
articles.abstract: The Bush administration allowed the purchase despite U.N. sanctions, according to U.S. officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 7 — Three months after the United States successfully pressed the United Nations to impose strict sanctions on North Korea because of the country’s nuclear test, Bush administration officials allowed Ethiopia to complete a secret arms purchase from the North, in what appears to be a violation of the restrictions, according to senior American officials.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Iraq Confronts Hussein Legacy Cast in Bronze
articles.snippet: Iraq is debating whether to save or destroy the scores of monuments Saddam Hussein built to honor himself.
articles.abstract: Iraq is debating whether to save or destroy the scores of monuments Saddam Hussein built to honor himself.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 7 — He was ousted, captured, tried and executed. But while the dictator may be gone, his legacy visibly lives on.

articles.headline: How the West Was Accumulated, Back East
articles.snippet: The mayor of Harrisburg, Pa., spent $7.8 million of public funds on items for an Old West museum he hoped to open.
articles.abstract: The mayor of Harrisburg, Pa., spent $7.8 million of public funds on items for an Old West museum he hoped to open.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa.

articles.headline: Transparency, Lost in the Fog
articles.snippet: In the world of executive compensation, fact often outstrips fiction, and even farce.
articles.abstract: In the world of executive compensation, fact often outstrips fiction, and even farce.
articles.lead_paragraph: POP quiz: What highly paid chief executive thought nothing of plunking down a thousand bucks for an ivory back scratcher?

articles.headline: H.P. Tries to Create Printers That Love the Web
articles.snippet: Hewlett-Packard is devising ways to get people to print Web pages instead of reading them on-screen.
articles.abstract: Hewlett-Packard is devising ways to get people to print Web pages instead of reading them on-screen.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vyomesh I. Joshi, the senior vice president in charge of Hewlett-Packard’s printing division, bounded up to the stage to congratulate his employees on their performance. He was ebullient, and with good reason: revenue, profit, margins and market share were all up, he told them at a quarterly “coffee talk” in late February.

articles.headline: Patterns of War Shift in Iraq Amid U.S. Buildup
articles.snippet: There is little sign that the security push in Baghdad is accomplishing its main purpose: creating an island of stability for Iraqis.
articles.abstract: There is little sign that the security push in Baghdad is accomplishing its main purpose: creating an island of stability for Iraqis.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, April 8 — Nearly two months into the new security push in Baghdad, there has been some success in reducing the number of death squad victims found crumpled in the streets each day.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Edward Wong

articles.headline: Democrats Seek to Lead the Way in Tax Overhaul
articles.snippet: New legislation would permanently shield all but the very richest taxpayers from the alternative minimum tax.
articles.abstract: New legislation would permanently shield all but the very richest taxpayers from the alternative minimum tax.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 8 — House Democratic leaders, in an effort to upstage Republicans on the issue of tax cuts, are preparing legislation that would permanently shield all but the very richest taxpayers from the alternative minimum tax, which is likely to affect tens of millions of families as early as next year if it is left unchanged.

articles.headline: With Imus, They Keep Coming Back
articles.snippet: Don Imus gives MSNBC a cheap way to compete in the morning despite his offensiveness toward all sorts of ethnicities, sexual orientations and religious affiliations.
articles.abstract: Don Imus gives MSNBC a cheap way to compete in the morning despite his offensiveness toward all sorts of ethnicities, sexual orientations and religious affiliations.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Imus in the Morning” is scheduled to start this morning like any other, with Don Imus and his crew cracking wise about the weekend’s events, riffing off the news and chatting with Evan Thomas, one of Newsweek’s top guns. Later Tom Oliphant, Washington author and former op-ed columnist for The Boston Globe, will check in for some political talk.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Moneymen Make a Play for Airwaves
articles.snippet: An investment group is preparing to compete for the valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when broadcasters convert to digital signals.
articles.abstract: An investment group is preparing to compete for the valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when broadcasters convert to digital signals.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 8 — Some of Silicon Valley’s most powerful venture capitalists and technology investors have joined an investment group that is preparing to challenge cellphone carriers, cable and satellite companies for valuable radio spectrum that will be freed when television broadcasters convert to digital signals.

articles.headline: A Call for Manners in the World of Nasty Blogs
articles.snippet: High-profile figures in high-tech are proposing a blogger code of conduct to clean up the quality of online discourse.
articles.abstract: High-profile figures in high-tech are proposing a blogger code of conduct to clean up the quality of online discourse.
articles.lead_paragraph: Is it too late to bring civility to the Web?

articles.headline: Genocide Court Ruled for Serbia Without Seeing Full War Archive
articles.snippet: Lawyers say Serbia kept full military archives from the International Court of Justice, where Bosnia was suing Serbia for genocide.
articles.abstract: Lawyers say Serbia kept full military archives from the International Court of Justice, where Bosnia was suing Serbia for genocide.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — In the spring of 2003, during the trial of Slobodan Milosevic, hundreds of documents arrived at the war crimes tribunal in The Hague marked “Defense. State Secret. Strictly Confidential.”

articles.headline: A Madison Avenue Deal Maker Continues His Spending Spree
articles.snippet: Miles S. Nadal, head of MDC Partners, is doing what he loves to do best: making deals. But when is enough enough?
articles.abstract: Miles S. Nadal, head of MDC Partners, is doing what he loves to do best: making deals. But when is enough enough?
articles.lead_paragraph: Miles S. Nadal, the Monty Hall of Madison Avenue, is at it again, doing what he loves to do best: making deals. But when is enough enough?

articles.headline: The Latest Real Estate Drama in the Hamptons Is About Newspaper Turf
articles.snippet: The introduction of The East Hampton Press as a competitor to The East Hampton Star involves a dynastic rivalry between its two owners.
articles.abstract: The introduction of The East Hampton Press as a competitor to The East Hampton Star involves a dynastic rivalry between its two owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. — On a recent Saturday morning in the offices of The East Hampton Star, the low moan of a fire siren came through an open window and David E. Rattray, the newspaper’s editor, sprang into action. Swiveling in his chair to his police scanner, he learned about a fire at a local retirement community and quickly called a photographer.
